journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part L: Journal of Materials: Design and Applications

title-group.article-title: Mechanical behaviours of calcium carbonate-impregnated short coir fibre-reinforced polyester composites

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Dhaanish Ahmed College of Engineering, Tamilnadu, India
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Mohamed Sathak Engineering College, Tamilnadu, India
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, A. C. College of Engineering and Technology, Tamilnadu, India

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mechanical Engineering, Dhaanish Ahmed College of Engineering, Chennai 601 301, Tamilnadu, India. email: ssathya1978@gmail.com

abstract.p: The tensile, flexural, and impact behaviours of calcium carbonate-impregnated coir fibre-reinforced polyester composites were evaluated. The short untreated coir fibres with different proportions of length, diameter, and filler content were used as reinforcements in polymer-based matrices. The fabricated composites with different levels of fibre parameters were tested as per ASTM standards. The mathematical models of mechanical behaviours were developed using statistical package. The effects of calcium carbonate on the mechanical properties of coir–polyester composites and prediction of mechanical properties using regression models were investigated.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The utilization of polymer composites in many engineering fields has undergone a marvellous increase. In the recent years, increasing environmental awareness, international government policy, new global agreements, and regulations have been directing attractiveness to a plant-based fibre as an alternative reinforcement material in polymer composites. Reduced weight and increased performance properties have paved a path to development of advanced engineering materials. Composite products have good mechanical properties-to-weight ratios, and the technologies permit the manufacture of complex and large shapes [1].

Composite manufacturing technologies allow the producer to attach more value to the product than the processing and trading of raw material. The expansion of new and more profitable markets will improve the position of the workers involved in this industry and increase their welfare also. Structural characteristics of coir fibre were evaluated and discussed in references [2, 3] and mechanical properties of coir fibre reinforcement in polyester matrix in reference [4]. The mathematical modelling and optimization of drilling behaviours in natural coir fibre-reinforced polyester composites were discussed by Jayabal and Natarajan [5, 6]. The evaluation of mechanical properties of randomly oriented coir fibre mixed with epoxy resin by Harish et al. [7] provided the possibility of development in coir–polymer composites.

Fillers are added to a polymer matrix to reduce cost (since most fillers are much less expensive than the matrix resin), increase modulus, reduce mould shrinkage, control viscosity, and produce smoother surface. The major constituents of particulate (filler added) composites are particles of mica, silica, glass spheres, calcium carbonate, or others. In general, these particles do not contribute to the load-carrying capacity of the material and act more like a filler than a reinforcement for the matrix. The most common filler for polyester and vinyl ester resins is calcium carbonate (CaCO3), which is used to reduce cost as well as mould shrinkage [8].

This study investigated the influence of calcium carbonate on the mechanical properties of coir–polyester composites. As per 33 full factorial design (three fibre parameters and three levels in each parameter), a total of 27 experimental runs were carried out in this investigation. The composites were fabricated as per full factorial design of fibre parameters, namely fibre length, fibre diameter, and filler content and the mechanical properties namely, tensile, flexural, and impact strengths were evaluated as per ASTM standards.

sec.title: 2.1 Applications of calcium carbonate in sheet-moulding compounds
sec.p: The calcium carbonate is mostly used in sheet-moulding compounds (SMC). They are thin sheets of fibres pre-compounded with a thermoset resin and used primarily in compression moulding process [8]. Common thermoset resins for SMC sheets are made of polyester. The higher cost of epoxies has limited their use in SMC. The nominal fibre content (by weight percent) is usually indicated by two-digit numbers after the letter R in SMC. SMC-R contains randomly oriented discontinuous fibres. The fibre content with weight percentage 30 was used in this investigation.

sec.title: 2.2 Composite fabrication
sec.p: The resin system consists of unsaturated orthophthalic polyester resin (specific gravity at 27 °C: 1.136, viscosity: 470 cPs, and mass per unit area: 449.96 g/m2), methyl ethyl ketone peroxide catalyst, and cobalt octoate accelerator were used. The resin properties such as specific gravity and viscosity were tested asper Indian Standard IS: 6746:1994 and mass wasdetermined as per ISO 3374 test methods atOCV Reinforcements Manufacturing Limited, Thimmapur, Andrapradesh, India. The resin, catalyst, and accelerator were mixed in the ratio 1:0.015:0.015.

The coir fibres were grouped in three levels by diameter values using 11× magnification in Machine Vision System (Make: Rapid-I) and three different lengths by cutting fibre bundles using sawing machine. The fibres were placed on the table and focused for getting the image of individual fibres using microscope available in Machine Vision System. The fibre shape was drawn using Drafting software in the system and diameter values were measured from the geometry.

The simple hand lay-up process was followed for fabricating calcium carbonate-impregnated coir–polyester composites. Poly vinyl acetate release agent was applied to the surfaces of mould before the fabrication. The calcium carbonate was mixed with the resin in 2 per cent and 4 per cent by weight. The resin coating was applied above the releasing agent by brush. The randomly oriented coir fibres were distributed over the resin coating and pressed heavily (1000 N) for 1 h. After 1 h, the composite was removed from the mould and cured at room temperature (29 °C) for 24 h. The same procedure was followed to prepare different types of CaCO3–coir–polyester composites as per full factorial design matrix. The photographic image of some of the fabricated composites is shown in Fig. 1. The composite plates were prepared for 3 mm thickness and the air bubble inclusions in hand lay-up process were avoided by applying load uniformly over the surface of the composite after the free flow of resin mix. Fig. 1
Photographic image of fabricated composites

sec.title: 2.3 Mechanical testing
sec.p:
Tensile behaviour of calcium carbonate–coir–polyester composites was measured using Universal Testing Machine (Make: Shimadzu and Model: AG-IS) at a cross-head speed of 5 mm/min. as per ASTM D638-08 standard. Specimens having approximate length, width, and thickness 165, 25, and 3 mm, respectively, were cut from the fabricated composite. Five identical specimens were tested to obtain the average tensile strength value. The photographic image of the tensile test specimens after fracture is shown in Fig. 2. Fig. 2
Photographic image of tensile test specimens after fracture

A rectangular test piece size of 127 × 12.7 × 3 mm3 for flexural test was cut from the prepared composites. The specimen was prepared as a beam and theload applied in the middle of the specimen. Three-point flexural test was conducted as per ASTM D790-07 in Instron machine (Model: 3382) using a load cell of 10 kN at 2.8 mm/min rate loading. Five identical specimens were tested to obtain the average flexural strength of composites. The photographic image of the generated fractured lines during flexural test is shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 3
Photographic image of flexural test specimens after fracture

Impact strength testing was carried out using impact testing machine (Make: ATS FAAR, Model: 16.1, and capacity of up to 25 J) as per ASTM D256-06 standard. Specimens having approximate length, width, and thickness 62.5, 6.25, and 3 mm, respectively, were cut from the fabricated composite. The test specimen was supported as a vertical cantilever beam and broken by a single swing of a pendulum. The pendulum strikes the face and a total of five samples were tested and the average value of the absorbed energy was taken. The photographic image of impact test specimens after fracture is shown in Fig. 4. Fig. 4
Photographic image of impact test specimens after fracture

sec.title: 2.4 Test of hypothesis
sec.p: If the experimental data are assumed to be normally distributed, quantiles of the normal distribution and the sample mean and standard error can be used to calculate approximate confidence intervals for the mean. Initially, null hypothesis, H0, and alternative hypothesis, H1, were set in t-test to study the existence of statistical significance in a set of observed values. The distribution given by the null hypothesis and perform a test to determine whether or not the null hypothesis should be rejected in favour of thealternative hypothesis. There are two different types of tests that can be performed. A one-tailed test looks for an increase or decrease in the parameter whereas a two-tailed test looks for any change in the parameter (which can be any change – increase or decrease). The two-tailed ANOVA test was performed in this investigation to analyse the effect of fibre parameters. The test is performed at 5 per cent confidence level meaning that there is a 5 per cent chance of wrongly rejecting H0. A decision is taken to reject the null hypothesis by saying ‘there is significant evidence at the 5 per cent level to suggest that the hypothesis is false’.

A t-test is any statistical hypothesis test in which the test statistic follows a Student’s t-distribution, if the null hypothesis is supported. It is most commonly applied when the test statistic would follow a normal distribution if the value of a scaling term in the test statistic were known. When the scaling term is unknown and replaced by an estimate based on the data, the test statistic (under certain conditions) follows a Student’s t-distribution [6].

sec.title: 3.1 Mechanical properties
sec.p:
The selected levels of fibre parameters are given in Table 1. The tested tensile, flexural, and impact properties of fabricated composites for different levels of fibre parameters are given in Table 2. The non-linear regression equations were developed for determining tensile, flexural, and impact strengths within the lower and upper limits of fibre parameters. The quadratic model was selected based on fit summary and R2 value. Coefficient of determination, R2, is used in the context of statistical models, whose main purpose is the prediction of future outcomes on the basis of other related information. It is the proportion of variability in a data set that is accounted for by the statistical model. It provides a measure of how well future outcomes are likely to be predicted by the model [6]. The predicted and adjusted R2 values of tensile, flexural, and impact strengths models are given in Table 3. Predicted R2 gives the measure of how good the model predicts a response value, whereas adjusted R2 gives the measure of the amount of variation about the mean in model. The closeness of predicted and adjusted R2 values exhibited the accuracy of the developed regression models Table 1

sec.title: 3.2 Analysis of variance
sec.p:
Analysis of variance is a collection of statistical models, and their associated procedures, in which the observed variance is partitioned into components due to different explanatory variables. sec.title: 3.3 Effects of fibre parameters
sec.p:
The comparison plot of tensile properties for different combinations of fibre parameters is shown in Fig. 5. Figures 6 and Figures 7 show the flexural and impact properties for different levels of fibre parameters. Based on two-tailed ANOVA test, the following observations were made. Value of probability of seeing ‘two-tailed t-test’ less than 0.05 indicated that the model terms were significant. Fig. 5
Tensile strength values for fabricated composites Fig. 6
Flexural strength values for fabricated composites Fig. 7
Impact strength values for fabricated composites

list-item.p: In tensile strength model, the most influencing parameters are fibre lengths followed by filler content and these fibre parameters are playing a major role in increasing this property. The interaction effects of fibre length and filler content are also playing a significant role.

In flexural strength model, the most influencing parameters are fibre length and filler content and these fibre parameters are playing a major role in increasing this property. The interaction effects of fibre length and filler content are also maximum.

In impact strength model also, the same result was obtained. The most influencing parameters are fibre length followed by filler content and the interaction effects of fibre length and filler content played a significant role. The fibre diameter is also playing a significant role on the improvement of impact properties.

For the 10-mm fibre length, the tensile properties are decreased by the addition of filler materials. The tensile properties are moderately higher for the filler content in weight percentage of 2 for the fibre lengths of 30 and 50 mm.
The flexural strength is decreased for the increase of filler content more than 2 per cent. Better values of flexural strength are also obtained at the 50-mm fibre length.

sec.title: 3.4 Fibre parameters for maximum value of responses
sec.p: Calcium carbonate fillers are used with polyester resin matrix primarily to reduce cost and to improve their dimensional stability. Fillers assist in reducing shrinkage of the moulded part, promote better fibre distribution during moulding, and reduce the overall cost of the compound. However, the mechanical properties of polyester resin and composites are affected by fillers. Better values of tensile strength 17.8 MPa and flexural strength 27.4 MPa were obtained for fibre length 50 mm, fibre diameter 0.18 mm, and calcium carbonate content 2 per cent. Higher impact strength of 39.7 kJ/m2 was obtained for fibre length 30 mm and fibre diameter 0.25 mm in this investigation.

sec.title: 3.5 Scanning electron microscopy analysis of fractured surfaces
sec.p:
The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis results of fractured surfaces after the tensile, flexural, and impact tests are shown in Figs 8, 9, and 10, respectively. The presence and distribution of calcium carbonate filler particles in the polyester resin matrix and on the fibre surface were studied using SEM images. The uniform distribution of calcium carbonate particles in resin system was found in the fractography of fracture surfaces. There was a fibre pull-out, indicating not much fibre–matrix interaction as there were only a few fibres, and they could not participate in stress transfer. At random distribution of fibres, there was an agglomeration of fibres, which led to the formation of bundles. These bundles acted as barriers to stress transfer, and so the interface was weak. There was fibre breakage because of the strong fibre–matrix adhesion as the population of fibres was just right for effective stress transfer. The matrix cracking, formation of fracture line, fibre pull-out, void formation, and fibre–resin compatibility were studied using SEM images. The matrix cracking was started on the fracture lines and voids were formed due to fibre pull-out in mechanical testing. The matrix plays a minor role in the tensile load-carrying capacity of a composite structure. However, the matrix has a major influence on the compressive, inter-laminar shear as well as in-plane shear properties of the composite material. Fig. 8
SEM images of fractured surfaces after tensile testing Fig. 9
SEM images of fractured surfaces after flexural testing Fig. 10
SEM images of fractured surfaces after impact testing

sec.title: 3.6 Validation of regression models
sec.p: Confirmation experiments were conducted for eight sets of conditions. The experimental and the predicted values obtained from regression models were compared. The percentage of error was calculated using the following formula (4) for validating the developed regression models.

From Table 7, it was observed that the average absolute error for tensile strength = 1.27 per cent, flexural strength = 1.20 per cent, and impact strength = 0.86 per cent, and better accuracy was obtained using the developed regression models. The closeness of predicted and experimental values for the mechanical properties is represented using Figs 11 to 13. Fig. 11
Comparison graph of predicted and experimental tensile strength values Fig. 12
Comparison graph of predicted and experimental flexural strength values Fig. 13

sec.title: 4 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The developed mathematical models significantly predicted the tensile, flexural, and impact propertieswith good accuracy. The maximum error deviation values of 3.04 per cent, 2.44 per cent, and 2.28 per cent were obtained in tensile, flexural, and impact strength models, respectively. Better values of tensile properties are obtained in all the levels of fibre length. The addition of calcium carbonate decreases impact properties, but the 2 per cent addition of calcium carbonate improved other mechanical properties. The fibre diameter of 0.18 mm generally gives better tensile and flexural properties, whereas the maximum fibre diameter (0.25 mm) gives better impact properties.
